The key is to strengthen ASEAN cooperation through ‚Äúminilateralism‚Äù in South China Sea and alienate China from our regional rule-making process until it reaches the conclusion that being excluded brings no strategic or tangible benefit. The Chinese must abide by the rule of law.

Moreover, apart from CoC with fellow ASEAN members, the Philippines should also initiate talks with some of its Southeast Asian neighbors to facilitate joint exploration in the South China Sea. Manila shouldn‚Äôt be tapping Beijing as a partner for this particular undertaking.

Doing so can help with confidence-building in ASEAN and send China a clear message that our bloc is committed to establishing and complying with norms so as to maintain relative peace & stability in our respective exclusive economic zones and prevent unwanted engagements.

While China remains staunchly opposed to the correct interpretation of UNCLOS, the Philippines should instead pursue and fast-track negotiations for the establishment of a code of conduct (CoC) with fellow Southeast Asian claimants and neighbors with stakes in South China Sea.
